From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
To: Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
CC:

Date: 2024-10-11 14:58
Subject: RE: Update on the 3-years insurance policies tender process
--------------------------------------------------
Hi Joe,

During the last Finance and Risk Committee presentation, I mentioned that if there was a significant likelihood of premium increases due to the heavy losses sustained by the insurance industry as a result of the April floods, we would launch a tender to manage potential cost increases.

 

However, we were able to renew the insurance portfolio without any premium increase for the UAE and all other countries. As a result, there was no need to break the current 3-year agreement and to initiate a fresh tender.

 

The only concession we agreed to make was an increase in the deductible for water damage in the UAE, from USD 400 to USD 2,000.

chunks.text:
The only concession we agreed to make was an increase in the deductible for water damage in the UAE, from USD 400 to USD 2,000. Given the current market conditions, this change is reasonable and is limited only to the UAE. The terms for all other countries remain unchanged.

 

The existing 3-year agreement will expire in September 2025. So for next year, we will initiate a fresh tender and include the procurement team to structure the process and all participants will be required to submit their proposals through the Ariba platform.

 

Do you want me to include high-level insurance costs for 2024-2025 in the update, or I just mention that, despite challenging market conditions, we successfully renewed the group’s insurance portfolio with no premium increase?


Best regards,

Hagop

 

HAGOP GHAZARIAN​​​​

From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
Date: Friday, 11 October 2024 at 2:58 PM
To: Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
Subject: RE: Update on the 3-years insurance policies tender process

Hi Joe,

During the last Finance and Risk Committee presentation, I mentioned that if there was a significant likelihood of premium increases due to the heavy losses sustained by the insurance industry as a result of the April floods, we would launch a tender to manage potential cost increases.

 

However, we were able to renew the insurance portfolio without any premium increase for the UAE and all other countries. As a result, there was no need to break the current 3-year agreement and to initiate a fresh tender.

 

The only concession we agreed to make was an increase in the deductible for water damage in the UAE, from USD 400 to USD 2,000. Given the current market conditions, this change is reasonable and is limited only to the UAE. The terms for all other countries remain unchanged.

 

The existing 3-year agreement will expire in September 2025. So for next year, we will initiate a fresh tender and include the procurement team to structure the process and all participants will be required to submit their proposals through the Ariba platform.

 

Do you want me to include high-level insurance costs for 2024-2025 in the update, or I just mention that, despite challenging market conditions, we successfully renewed the group’s insurance portfolio with no premium increase?

From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com <mailto:Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com> >
Date: Friday, 11 October 2024 at 2:58 PM
To: Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com <mailto:Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com> >
Subject: RE: Update on the 3-years insurance policies tender process

Hi Joe,

During the last Finance and Risk Committee presentation, I mentioned that if there was a significant likelihood of premium increases due to the heavy losses sustained by the insurance industry as a result of the April floods, we would launch a tender to manage potential cost increases.

 

However, we were able to renew the insurance portfolio without any premium increase for the UAE and all other countries. As a result, there was no need to break the current 3-year agreement and to initiate a fresh tender.

 

The only concession we agreed to make was an increase in the deductible for water damage in the UAE, from USD 400 to USD 2,000.

chunks.text:
The only concession we agreed to make was an increase in the deductible for water damage in the UAE, from USD 400 to USD 2,000. Given the current market conditions, this change is reasonable and is limited only to the UAE. The terms for all other countries remain unchanged.

 

The existing 3-year agreement will expire in September 2025. So for next year, we will initiate a fresh tender and include the procurement team to structure the process and all participants will be required to submit their proposals through the Ariba platform.

 

Do you want me to include high-level insurance costs for 2024-2025 in the update, or I just mention that, despite challenging market conditions, we successfully renewed the group’s insurance portfolio with no premium increase?


Best regards,

Hagop

 

HAGOP GHAZARIAN​​​​
